child_pages.title: Explore options for employers
child_pages.summary: This page provides information for employers seeking to hire overseas workers when suitable Australian workers are not available. It outlines visa options, sponsorship requirements, steps to nominate workers, and the work rights associated with different visa types. The page also highlights specific categories such as sponsored visas, Temporary Graduate visas, and other visas with work rights.

child_pages.title: Hiring someone in Australia
child_pages.summary: This page explains how employers in Australia must verify that a person is legally allowed to work before hiring them. It outlines steps for checking citizenship, permanent residency, and visa work entitlements using VEVO. It also details what is and is not acceptable evidence and provides guidance on ongoing visa checks.

visa_holders.unrestricted: Some visa holders can work without limits
visa_holders.restricted: Some visa holders can only work limited hours
visa_holders.no_work: Some visa holders cannot work at all

hiring_steps.step_1: Check if the person is an Australian citizen.

step_2.description: If not a citizen, check if they are a permanent resident.
acceptable_evidence: Evidence of holding an Australian permanent visa

step_3.description: If not a citizen or permanent resident, verify their visa work entitlements.
how_to_check: Ask the person to email their current visa details from VEVO
Use VEVO with the visa holder’s permission
requirements_to_hire: No breach of other visa conditions
Visa permits the type of work

step_4.description: Ensure the employee has valid work rights for the entire employment period.
ongoing_checks: Check visa within 2 days of expiry
Check sooner if visa circumstances change
For bridging visas without an expiry date in VEVO, check every 3 months
methods: Ask employee to send VEVO details
Use VEVO with permission and travel documents

child_pages.title: How to sponsor a worker
child_pages.summary: This page provides an overview of the steps employers must follow to sponsor a skilled worker in Australia. It outlines requirements such as labour market testing, selecting an eligible occupation, checking sponsor eligibility, nominating a position, and the worker completing a visa application. It also references additional resources and conditions depending on the visa type chosen.

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Labour market testing
requirements: Employer must show they cannot find a suitable person in Australia to fill the vacancy
Must provide evidence of labour market testing meeting formal requirements
Some occupations are exempt from labour market testing

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Occupation eligibility
requirements: Occupation must be on the list of eligible skilled occupations
If not listed, employer may be able to negotiate a labour agreement
Some visa options exist for highly paid or specialist skilled applicants
Worker may need to provide qualifications, skills, and/or experience evidence
Employer must pay at least the applicable market salary rate
Nominated occupation determines applicable visa options

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Select a suitable visa
notes: Employer should find a visa that suits both the employee and business needs
VEVO can be used to check the worker’s eligibility

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Check sponsor eligibility
notes: Employer must ensure they and their business meet sponsorship eligibility requirements

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Apply to become a sponsor
requirements: Employer must become an approved sponsor and/or nominator
May apply to be an accredited sponsor depending on visa type
Accredited sponsors receive priority processing
Additional information available under Becoming a sponsor or nominator

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Nominate the occupation
requirements: Employer must nominate the occupation or position as required for the visa type
Must include details of the person to fill the role
Position must generally be on a relevant skilled occupation list

sponsorship_process_steps.title: Visa application
requirements: The skilled worker is responsible for completing the visa application
Employer should ensure nominee meets eligibility criteria
Some workers may require a skills assessment from the correct assessing authority

key_links_referenced: Visa options for sponsored skilled workers

child_pages.title: Worker rights
child_pages.summary: This page provides information about workplace rights for all workers in Australia, including overseas workers. It explains employer obligations, clarifies that only the Australian Government can cancel visas, and highlights required pay and workplace conditions.

worker_rights.visa_protection: Employers cannot cancel or change a worker's visa or visa conditions; only the Australian Government can do this.
workplace_protections_apply_to: People from overseas working in Australia

minimum_requirements: Provide at least the minimum wage or the relevant market salary rate (for sponsored visas)
Provide payslips, superannuation, and tax documents
Ensure legal pay rates, leave conditions, shift arrangements, and dismissal processes equivalent to Australian employees

child_pages.title: Employer responsibilities
child_pages.summary: This page outlines employer and sponsorship responsibilities under Australia’s immigration framework. It explains when sponsors must contact the Department of Home Affairs, consequences for failing to meet obligations, and the types of sanctions that may be imposed. It also provides information on how to pay infringement notices.

when_to_contact_department: When there is a change relating to the sponsored person

general: Cancellation of approval as a sponsor
detailed_sanctions: Cancellation of approval as a sponsor
Being banned from sponsoring other workers
Being banned from making future applications for approval
Infringement notices with financial penalties (amount varies for individuals vs. body corporates and first vs. subsequent notices)
Civil penalties (up to $82,500 for corporations, $16,500 for individuals per failure)

child_pages.title: Business, industry and regional outreach
child_pages.summary: This page explains the role of the Department's Business, Industry and Regional Outreach (BIRO) officers, who provide information on migration to businesses, industry groups, government agencies, and regional stakeholders. It also clarifies that BIRO officers cannot provide individual migration advice and directs users to registered migration agents or legal practitioners for assistance.

biro_officer_audience: industry including professional and industry associations and unions
structured_data.biro_officer_role: Provide information on migration and visa pathway options to help employers fill vacant positions where Australian workers are unavailable.

child_pages.title: Migrant worker protections
child_pages.summary: This page explains new Australian laws introduced under the Migration Amendment (Strengthening Employer Compliance) Act 2024, aimed at protecting migrant workers from exploitation. It outlines what constitutes exploitation, who is protected, penalties for non‑compliance, and the new prohibition declaration for employers. Resources such as videos, translated materials, and further information links are also provided.

who_is_covered.coverage: All migrant workers regardless of visa status
examples: Workers with visas that include work rights

examples_of_exploitation: Pressuring a worker to exceed visa‑allowed work hours
Pressuring a worker to accept inadequate living conditions
new_offences: Coercing or pressuring a temporary visa holder to breach a work‑related visa condition

penalties.description: People who deliberately, seriously or repeatedly break the laws can be fined or jailed.
penalties.additional_measures: Some employers may be prevented from hiring additional migrant workers.

prohibition_declaration.description: A measure that stops certain employers from hiring more migrant workers.
prohibition_declaration.public_listing: Names and ABNs of prohibited employers will be published on the Australian Border Force website.
